cards.front: State Ohm's law in both resistance and conductance form.
cards.back: v = Ri (resistance form) and i = Gv (conductance form), where G = 1/R.

cards.front: On the v-i plane, what is the slope of a linear resistor's characteristic?
cards.back: Slope = G = 1/R (conductance in siemens). Larger R means shallower slope.

cards.front: On the i-v plane, what is the slope of a linear resistor's characteristic?
cards.back: Slope = R (resistance in ohms). Larger R means steeper slope.

cards.front: What is the unit of conductance?
cards.back: Siemens (S). G = 1/R. A 100-ohm resistor has conductance G = 0.01 S = 10 mS.

cards.front: What is the associated reference direction?
cards.back: Current flows into the terminal marked positive. Under this convention, v = Ri holds directly and p = vi gives absorbed power.

cards.front: What does 'bilateral' mean for a resistor?
cards.back: f(v, i) = f(-v, -i) for all (v, i) on the characteristic. The v-i curve is symmetric about the origin. A linear resistor is always bilateral.

cards.front: What does 'memoryless' mean for a resistor?
cards.back: The current at time t depends only on the voltage at time t, not on past values. i(t) = Gv(t) with no derivatives or integrals involved.

cards.front: When is the linear resistor model inadequate for a physical resistor?
cards.back: At excessive voltages/currents (breakdown), at very high frequencies (parasitic capacitance/inductance), or when temperature effects matter significantly.

cards.front: For parallel resistors, which quantity adds directly?
cards.back: Conductances add: G_total = G1 + G2 + ... (This is dual to series resistors where R_total = R1 + R2.)
